tossups.question: This book's third section discusses a debate over whether words meaning "to revel" or "to wander from village to village" are the origin of the word "comedian". This book's last section considers a critique of "histrionic" art which is exaggerated by gesticulation and argues that it applies equally to two forms, which each produce effect "without action". This book argues in favor of "complex" rather than "simple" structures, but against the use of double endings and (*) subjects, and begins by considering the medium, object, and manner of imitation, or mimesis ("MIH-meh-sis"). It argues that moments of reversal, or peripeteia, and cleansing effects, or katharsis, are created by the plots of proper tragedies. The three classical unities were derived from, for 10 points, what literary treatise by Aristotle?
tossups.answer: Poetics [or Peri poetikes; or De Poetica]

tossups.question: An ethnically Norwegian mayor of this US city said "I am tired out and am going fishing" when he resigned after being targeted by the IWW with a booby-trapped bomb. That mayor, Ole Hanson, intervened against this city's Bolshevik-inspired 1919 general strike for wages. It's not Oakland, but in preparation for another event in this city, the Ruckus Society hosted a training camp led by John Sellers, who described events here as (*) "teamsters and turtles dancing in the streets." During that event, sometimes called N-30, this city's mayor Paul Schell imposed a 50-block "no-protest zone" after "black bloc" anarchists smashed windows during talks for the Millennium Round. For 10 points, what city saw a so-called "battle" during a 1999 WTO meeting and the 2020 Capital Hill Autonomous Zone protest?
tossups.answer: Seattle [accept Seattle General Strike or Battle of Seattle]

tossups.question: Tannaka and Krein constructed a duality between groups with this property and categories of representations, generalizing the duality between abelian groups that locally have this property and characters found by Pontryagin. This property is equivalent to every ultrafilter converging. Every sequence having a convergent subsequence is this property's sequential form, which for metric (*) spaces is equivalent to this property. The axiom of choice is equivalent to the statement that any product of sets with this property has this property, Tychonoff's theorem. A subset of Euclidean space has this property if and only if it's closed and bounded by the Heine-Borel theorem. For 10 points, name this property of a topological space in which any open cover has a finite subcover.
tossups.answer: compactness

tossups.question: Irenaeus wrote that the Carpocratians had one of these objects supposedly made by Pontius Pilate. John of Damascus is most noted for writing about these objects. Many visitors to a church named for the settlement of Tolmachi view one of these objects of the Eleusa type. In some designs of churches, a wall of these objects stands in for the Temple Veil and separates the nave from the sanctuary; those walls are called these objects' namesake (*) stasis. One of them from St. Catherine’s Monastery was inspired by John Climacus's Ladder of Divine Ascent. When these objects are allegedly miraculously-created, they're called acheiropoieta, or "made without hands", such as the Mandylion from Edessa. Leo the Isaurian inaugurated a ban on these objects in the Byzantine empire. For 10 points, name these Christian sacred images.
tossups.answer: icons [before the end, prompt on Christian/religious/sacred/devotional/etc. images or images of specific Christian holy figures, or any reasonably equivalent description that doesn't explicitly contain the word "icon"; accept iconostasis]
tossups.answer_formatted: icons [before the end, prompt on Christian/religious/sacred/devotional/etc. images or images of specific Christian holy figures, or any reasonably equivalent description that doesn't explicitly contain the word "icon"; accept iconostasis]

tossups.question: Several birds endemic to this mountain range, including its namesake geese and crested ducks, have increased cardiac ability as adaptations to hypoxia. Many black chested buzzard-eagles live in this range, as does the black-chested mountain caracara. Adaptive radiation in this range has produced about 40% of the world's hummingbird species, including the giant hummingbird and the hillstars. A plateau in this range is home to James's (*) flamingo and this range's own namesake flamingo. Bird-watchers frequent areas of its slopes such as the Bellavista Reserve and the cloud forest of Yungas. The largest flying land-bird both by weight and by wingspan is this range's namesake condor. Many birds are found in the Altiplano surrounded by, for 10 points, what mountain range of western South America?
tossups.answer: Andes Mountains [or Andean Mountains; or Cordillera de los Andes; accept Andean condor / flamingo / geese / crested duck, etc.]
tossups.answer_formatted: Andes Mountains [or Andean Mountains; or Cordillera de los Andes; accept Andean condor / flamingo / geese / crested duck, etc.]
acceptable: Andean condor / flamingo / geese / crested duck, etc.

tossups.question: In a book framed as dialogues with students at Columbia's film school, this author exhorts the students to "think visually". This author adapted the satirical novel American Hero into a screenplay for a film in which the president is caught making sexual advances in the Oval Office, titled Wag the Dog. This author of On Directing Film wrote a play in which a movie by Doug Brown is green-lit instead of a movie about the apocalyptic effects of (*) radiation, despite the efforts of the activist Karen. In the film adaptation of another of this author's plays, the lines "I'm here for Mitch and Murray!" and "the leads are weak? you're weak!" are delivered by Alec Baldwin, who yells "Coffee's for closers!" to Shelly Levene. For 10 points, name this playwright of Speed-the-Plow and Glengarry Glen Ross.
tossups.answer: David Mamet

tossups.question: The distance that a disturbance in this quantity can propagate is given by a namesake "diffusion length" symbolized lambda. Electric currents change values of this quantity in "racetrack" memory. GMR thin-films can form namesake "valves" in a type of electronics that relies on changes in this quantity. Products of neighboring values of this quantity appear in the Hamiltonian of the Heisenberg model, which imagines values of this quantity at each (*) point of a lattice. This quantity's existence was shown by shooting silver atoms through a spatially-varying magnetic field in the Stern-Gerlach experiment. Ground state electron configurations seek to align values of this quantity according to Hund's rule. For 10 points, what quantity's value for an electron equals plus or minus one-half?
tossups.answer: spin [or intrinsic angular momentum; prompt on angular momentum; do not accept or prompt on "orbital angular momentum"]
tossups.answer_formatted: spin [or intrinsic angular momentum; prompt on angular momentum; do not accept or prompt on "orbital angular momentum"]

tossups.question: Teven Say is one of the only remaining Khmer practitioners of an art form executed on this material that involves fervently chanting in Pali prior to completing a work. The Spanish called artists from the Philippines who made works on this material pintados, an example of whom was "Prince Giolo" ("hee-OH-loh"). Patterns such as the jagged taratarekae ("tah-rah-tah-reh-kah-eh") are used in an art form done on this material which is executed using a chisel made of albatross bone called an uhi. That (*) Maori art form done on this material is called ta moko. Thermal transfer paper is often used to create modern works on this material. Red or golden dyes are applied to this material as part of mehndi ceremonies prior to Hindu weddings. For 10 points, henna is applied to what material, which is subjected to ink when creating tattoos?
tossups.answer: human skin [accept the human body; accept specific body parts such as the face or back]
tossups.answer_formatted: human skin [accept the human body; accept specific body parts such as the face or back]
acceptable: specific body parts such as the face

tossups.question: After a ruler of this kingdom imported three electric chairs into his country, he used one of them as his throne. That ruler of this kingdom hired the Swiss engineer Alfred Ilg to build a railroad from his capital. Another ruler of this kingdom commissioned the mortar Sebastopol and committed suicide with a pistol gifted by Queen Victoria at the Battle of Magdala. Nikolay Leontiev modernized this kingdom's army ten years after it signed the Treaty of (*) Wuchale. During this kingdom's "Era of Princes," ethnic groups such as the Agaw and Tigray vied for dominance following the death of its king Iyasu II. After acquiring British weaponry, it defeated Oreste Baratieri's forces at the Battle of Adowa. For 10 points, name this kingdom which was ruled by Menelik II during the Scramble for Africa.
tossups.answer: Ethiopian Empire [or Ityoppya; or Abyssinia]

tossups.question: In the Anabasis, Xenophon notes that a Greek army was briefly incapacitated by unknowingly consuming a toxic form of this substance which contains grayanotoxin, known as is its "mad" variety. In Oedipus Rex, the chorus advises the title character to pour water mixed with this substance on the ground, as it was said to please chthonic deities. The Greeks credited the first human uses of olive oil, cheese, and this substance to a figure who attempted to rape Eurydice named (*) Aristaeus. This substance nursed the nymph Melissa, who was named for it, in her youth. It supposedly filled the sarcophagus of Alexander the Great. This substance was fermented to make the first alcoholic drinks, such as mead. Apiculturists often seek to acquire, for 10 points, what sweet liquid made by bees?
tossups.answer: honey [accept melis before "Melissa"]

tossups.question: This composer wrote that "music to Berlioz is like the snake to Laocoön" ("lay-AH-kuh-wahn") in his review of Symphonie fantastique ("sahn-foh-NEE fahn-tahs-TEEK") and conceived his String Quartet No. 1 in A minor as a response to Hector Berlioz. Late in life, this composer edited the music journal Neue Zeitschrift für Musik ("NOY-uh ZYTE-shrift fuer MOO-zeek"), in which he published the article "New Paths". His first essay of criticism created a fictional music society named (*) Davidsbündler ("DAH-veeds-buehnd-lur"), which names one of his piano suites. Aspects of this composer's personality named "Florestan" and "Eusebius" name movements of another of his piano suites, which depicts a raucous pre-Lent celebration. This composer vigorously championed his protégé Johannes Brahms, who later fell in love with his widow. For 10 points, name this composer of Carnaval who married Clara Wieck ("veek").
tossups.answer: Robert Schumann [prompt on Schumann]

tossups.question: The beliefs by which these systems rationalize or justify their structures were termed their namesake "ideologies" by Michael Silverstein, which inspired an analysis of how these systems "construct difference" by Susan Gal and Judith Irvine. An incomplete treatise on one of these systems from Java articulates the notion that they are central to Weltansichten ("VELT-an-seesht-en") and is by Wilhelm von Humboldt. A popular quip claims these systems differ from less standard counterparts by having "an (*) army and navy". A paradigm (emphasize) first developed to study these systems was applied to kinship in Mythologiques ("mee-toh-loh-ZHEEK") by Claude Levi-Strauss. These systems influence relative perceptions of time according to the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis, based on study of the Hopi one. For 10 points, name these systems governed by grammars.
tossups.answer: languages [prompt on dialects]

tossups.question: Read answer carefully. Tito Livio Burattini proposed an early version of this policy which he referred to as "cattolico". Thomas Jefferson's attempt to enact this policy was derailed when Joseph Dombey's ship was captured by pirates. Only two of sixteen marble guides that were installed as part of this policy still remain. At the urging of the Marquis de Condorcet, an arc from Dunkirk to Barcelona was surveyed prior to enacting this policy. (*) Napoleon partially reversed this policy by reintroducing the livre and toise as part of the mesures usuelles. Since 1875, this system has been regulated by the General Conference on Weights and Measures. For 10 points, the French Revolution led to the creation of what measurement system with kilograms and meters?
tossups.answer: metric system [or système métrique; accept metrication or métrification; accept any description of creating/using/etc. the metric system; do not accept or prompt on answers with "SI", "système international (d'unités)", or "international system (of units)"; prompt on any description of creating/using/etc. standard units, measurements, measures, or weights that doesn't explicitly say "metric"; before mentioned, antiprompt on descriptions of creating/using/etc. the meter or kilogram]
tossups.answer_formatted: metric system [or système métrique; accept metrication or métrification; accept any description of creating/using/etc. the metric system; do not accept or prompt on "answers with "SI", "système international"]
acceptable: any description of creating/using/etc. the metric system

tossups.question: Robert Herrick envisioned a "dark" one of these places in a poem about a "curious twist" enthralling the arm of the Countess of Carlisle. A poem set at one of these locations imagines "When flowing Cups run swiftly round / With no allaying Thames" and discusses "Fishes that tipple in the Deep" and "Angels alone that soar above". A poem titled for one of these locations describes a man with a "cricket cap" on his head walking "among the (*) Trial Men / in a suit of shabby grey". That poem set in one of these places repeats the refrain "The man had killed the thing he loved / And so he had to die". In a Richard Lovelace poem about "my divine Althea," "stone walls" do not make one of these places. For 10 points, what sort of place in Reading ("RED-ing") names a "Ballad" by Oscar Wilde?
tossups.answer: prison [accept jail; or Reading Gaol]

tossups.question: Abnormal effects due to exposure to these particles may characterize one structure as "Argyll-Robertson" or "Marcus-Gunn". Porfimer sodium is used alongside a beam of these particles to treat some cancers and Barrett's esophagus. In a technique pioneered by Karl Deisseroth, these particles control neuronal firing. The release of these particles in a chain reaction beginning with pyrophosphate is the basis of a DNA sequencing method. The prokaryotic uvr system breaks up (*) cyclobutane rings formed when these particles are exposed to two pyrimidines. These particles cause one compound to isomerize from its 11-cis form to its all-trans form, allowing it to activate rhodopsins. The most prominent regulator of human circadian rhythms is, for 10 points, what particles absorbed by chlorophylls?
tossups.answer: photons

tossups.question: In the Poetic Edda, Sigrdrífa ("see-gur-DREE-fah") mentions a group of these things called the "ale" ones, which may reflect the alu motif from the Migration Era. In the Hávamál, a character recalls screaming as he lifted these things from the deep after enduring without food or drink for nine days. Men such as Öpir and Fot are among the hundreds of named "masters" of these things from medieval Sweden, where such men often also served as (*) skalds. These things, which begin with Feoh, Ura, and Thurs, have a collective name derived from the first six of them, "Futhark". Several of these things adorned the spear Gungnir after its owner, Odin, gained knowledge of them by hanging himself from Yggradsil. Viking sorcerers are thought to have cast spells by carving, for 10 points, what letters used to write Old Norse?
tossups.answer: runes [or runestones; accept rune masters or ale runes; before "Futhark", accept (Elder or Younger) Futhark; prompt on Norse letters]
tossups.answer_formatted: runes [or runestones; accept rune masters or ale runes; before "Futhark", accept]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. In 1974, the Zangger Committee developed a "trigger list" to rigorously enforce this goal. After signing the Treaty of Tlatelolco, various Latin American countries created the OPANAL to enforce this goal. Los Angeles businessman David Mixner funded a 1986 march from Los Angeles to Washington D.C. in support of this cause. Eisaku Satō ("eye-SAH-koo SAH-toe") won the Nobel Peace Prize for formally committing Japan to this goal. (*) Israel has controversially refused to sign a 1970 international treaty regarding this goal. Prior to being blown up, the Rainbow Warrior promoted this goal. The United States took steps to achieve this goal through the SALT I and II treaties. For 10 points, give this general goal of treaties which seek to prevent the spread of weapons of mass destruction.
tossups.answer: nuclear non-proliferation [accept descriptions involving the reduction in nuclear weapons before "weapons"; prompt on arms reduction or equivalents by asking "What sort of weapons do they target?"]
tossups.answer_formatted: nuclear non-proliferation [accept descriptions involving the reduction in nuclear weapons before "weapons; prompt on arms reduction or equivalents by asking "What sort of weapons do they target?]
acceptable: descriptions involving the reduction in nuclear weapons
promptable: equivalents by asking "What sort of weapons do they target?

tossups.question: Barbara Hepworth created three sculptures in homage to Piet Mondrian ("peet MON-dree-ahn") named for resembling this scene. Another artist had stuntman Russell Saunders model for a version of this scene that depicts two men pulling a boat ashore at its bottom. David Bowie's song Joe the Lion references Chris Burden's replication of this scene using a Volkswagen. A red-and-yellow photograph titled (*) Immersion controversially depicted a sculpture of this scene immersed in Andres Serrano's urine. Another version of this scene shows a burning scroll and a green-clad Wandering Jew at the bottom. Salvador Dalí painted a version of this scene from above after seeing a circular drawing by John of the Cross, as well as a version with a hypercube. For 10 points, Marc Chagall ("shuh-GALL") painted a "white" version of what religious scene?
tossups.answer: Crucifixion of Jesus Christ [prompt on Trans-Fixed, Piss Christ, and Christ of Saint John of the Cross by asking "what scene does that work intend to depict?"]
tossups.answer_formatted: Crucifixion of Jesus Christ [prompt on Trans-Fixed, Piss Christ, and Christ of Saint John of the Cross by asking "what scene does that work intend to depict?]

tossups.question: The site of one of these events rises "of its own volition" due to the frenzied efforts of the sawmill worker Rider in the story "Pantaloon in Black". Just before one of these events, music from a gramophone plays as a father searches a house for a tool for ten minutes, after his son insists that event should proceed despite his bad leg. Gavin Stevens funds one of these events for Joe Christmas in the novel Light in August and one for Samuel Beauchamp in the title story of Go Down, Moses. In another novel, (*) Dewey Dell and Jewel start a brawl after one of these events, resulting in Darl being sent to an asylum, after their family fulfills their mother's wishes by holding one for her in Jefferson, Mississippi. For 10 points, what sort of event is held for Addie Bundren in As I Lay Dying?
tossups.answer: funerals [or burials] (The clues are all from the works of William Faulkner.)
tossups.metadata: The clues are all from the works of William Faulkner.

tossups.question: An acetate salt of zinc and this element was used in the first-developed method for quantification of serum sodium levels. The alkali metals, the ammonium cation, and this element form the only soluble carbonates. Adding this element's oxide to glass makes it fluoresce green under UV light. Formate and acetate salts of this element are frequently used as negative stains in electron microscopy. This element's (*) hexafluoride is vaporized for use in the gas diffusion and gas centrifugation methods for separating its isotopes. The ore pitchblende is rich in this element, which is often delivered for chemical applications in its "depleted" form. For 10 points, name this radioactive heavy metal whose 235 isotope undergoes nuclear fission.
tossups.answer: uranium [or U]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about author Arundhati Roy's activism:
answers: Kashmir [accept Jammu and Kashmir; accept Azad Kashmir]
Maoism [prompt on Marxism or Leninism or Marxism-Leninism or communism]
parts: Roy has long supported the self-determination of this northernmost-region of India, control over which has been disputed with Pakistan since independence.
Roy criticized the government for taking military action against the Naxalites, who are followers of this ideology. The essays On Contradiction and On Practice are foundational to this ideology.

Roy opposed the Sardar Sarovar Dam because it was being built on the land of people denoted by this term, which collectively refers to Indian minority groups who are considered indigenous to their respective regions.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about early Russian expansion into Siberia:
answers: Kazan [accept Kazan Khanate or Kazan Cathedral]
parts: The pioneering explorer of Siberia, Yermak, was a hetman of these semi-nomadic, warlike Slavic people. Many of them lived on the banks of the Don river.
The expansion was facilitated by Ivan the Terrible's conquest of this Tatar city, which he celebrated by building a cathedral in Moscow named for it. Today, this city is the capital of Tatarstan.

To solidify its control of Siberia, as well as later Alaska, Russia built many examples of these buildings known as ostrogi. These small forts, which are similar to pillboxes, contain small holes to fire weapons from.

bonuses.leadin: The speaker of a poem by this poet laments "no woman's hand / will come down and fight for your fistful of bone!" For 10 points each:
answers: Gabriela Mistral [or Lucila Godoy Alcayaga] (Those are the Sonnets of Death.)
Chile [or Republic of Chile; or República de Chile]
parts: Name this author of the collections Desolación and Tala, who lamented the suicide of Romelio Ureta ("roh-MEH-lee-oh oo-REH-tah") in a prize-winning sequence of modernist sonnets.
Mistral was from this South American country, which also produced the author of Canto General ("KAHN-toh heh-neh-RAHL"), Pablo Neruda.

Mistral dedicated her "Poema del hijo" ("poh-EH-mah del EE-hoh") to this friend of hers. The lines "You want me like dawn / You want me made of sea-foam" open this Argentine author's poem "You Want Me White".
metadata: Those are the Sonnets of Death.

bonuses.leadin: This tactic is supported by "mafia behavior" in species such as the brown-headed cowbird. For 10 points each:
answers: brood parasitism [accept brood parasites; prompt on parasitism or parasites]
mimicry [accept egg mimicry; accept aggressive mimicry or Peckhamian mimicry; accept Batesian mimicry]
parts: Name this reproductive strategy seen in many birds, in which one organism places its eggs in another species's nest, so the other species will raise their young.

The eggs of brood parasites often resemble those of their hosts, an example of this phenomenon. In another example, cuckoos scare off other birds to lay eggs in their nests by looking like sparrowhawks.
In cuckoos, genetic and evolutionary factors cause the creation of these lineages, which only place their eggs in the nest of a specific other species.
answers_formatted: mimicry [accept egg mimicry; accept aggressive mimicry or Peckhamian mimicry; accept Batesian mimicry]

bonuses.leadin: In a 1992 article, B. Ruby Rich coined the term for a "new" type of cinema described by this adjective, citing such recent films as My Own Private Idaho as examples. For 10 points each:
answers: queer [or queering; accept New Queer Cinema; accept Flaming Classics: Queering the Film Canon]
parts: Give this adjective. Its verb form appears in the title of a 2000 Alexander Doty book titled for "Flaming Classics" of the film canon.

Rich credits this 1990 documentary by Jeannie Livingston with introducing a wide popular audience to queer cinema. This film explores New York City drag culture through a competition held by the title artist, surnamed Duprée.
Rich later identified this 2005 Ang Lee film as changing the direction of New Queer Cinema. It follows the relationship between two cattle herders in 1960s Wyoming.
answers_formatted: queer [or queering; accept New Queer Cinema; accept Flaming Classics: Queering the Film Canon]
acceptable: Flaming Classics: Queering the Film Canon

bonuses.leadin: A tensor corresponding to the inverse of this quantity equals the product of the photoelasticity tensor and the strain tensor. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity which, for anisotropic media, is a tensor relating the displacement and electric fields. The "relative" value of this quantity is the dielectric constant.
The standard electric permittivity of this medium is 8.85 times 10 to the negative 12th Farads per meter.
Because the complex permittivity is analytic on the upper half plane, one can use these integral identities to relate the complex permittivity's real and imaginary parts.

bonuses.leadin: This holiday's elaborate decorations include seven types with symbolic meanings and the largest celebration of it is in Sendai. For 10 points each:
answers: Tanabata [prompt on star festival or festival of stars, etc. or hoshi matsuri; do not accept or prompt on "Qīxī" or "Chilseok"]
the Cowherd AND the Weaver Girl [or Niúláng AND Zhīnǚ; or Hikoboshi AND Orihime; or Kengyuusei AND Shokujosei; or Gyuurou AND Shokujo; accept answers in either order]
Milky Way [or Amanogawa; or Gingakei; or Yínhéxì; or Tiānhé; or Xīnghé; or Tiānhàn]
parts: Name this holiday in which paper wish tags are hung on bamboo stalks. Since this festival absorbed one in which shrine maidens wove sacred cloths, it's named for a type of loom.
Tanabata celebrates a story of Chinese origin in which these two people reunite once per year, connected by a bridge of magpies. You may give their English, Japanese, or Chinese names.
The mythical bridge of magpies crosses this celestial object, which many people conceived of as a river in the sky.
answers_formatted: Tanabata [prompt on star festival or festival of stars, etc. or hoshi matsuri; do not accept or prompt on "Qīxī" or "Chilseok"]
the Cowherd AND the Weaver Girl [or Niúláng AND Zhīnǚ; or Hikoboshi AND Orihime; or Kengyuusei AND Shokujosei; or Gyuurou AND Shokujo; accept answers in either order]
Milky Way [or Amanogawa; or Gingakei; or Yínhéxì; or Tiānhé; or Xīnghé; or Tiānhàn]
acceptable: the Cowherd AND the Weaver Girl

bonuses.leadin: This short story begins in second person, noting that "actually she's your fiancé, but hey, in a bit it so won't matter". For 10 points each:
answers: Yunior de las Casas [accept either underlined portion]
parts: Name this final story of the collection This is How You Lose Her. Its narrator tries to put his life back together after the end of a relationship in which he was unfaithful for six years.

This personification of machismo is the protagonist of "The Cheater's Guide to Love". He narrates the novel The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao, in which he advises the protagonist to start lifting weights.
Both "The Cheater's Guide to Love" and The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao are by this Dominican-American author.

bonuses.leadin: In archaeology, pre-ceramic Andean cultures are part of a "stage" denoted by this word. For 10 points each:
answers: lithic [accept Neolithic age; accept Lithic stage]
pit-houses [accept sunken featured buildings or SFBs; accept grubhouses, grubenhauser, or grubhuts]
parts: Give this word from the Greek for "stone". When prefixed by "neo-," it denotes the age when agricultural communities began to form.

Both pre-ceramic Andean cultures and this one, considered ancestral to many Native American cultures, existed in the Lithic stage. Not to be confused with a Dark Age king, it is best known for its distinct arrowheads.
Clovis and pre-ceramic Andean cultures both built these dwellings, which are named because their floors are slightly dug into the earth. They were common among ancient peoples of New Mexico.
answers_formatted: pit-houses [accept sunken featured buildings or SFBs; accept grubhouses, grubenhauser, or grubhuts]

bonuses.leadin: A fresco of Hercules stealing some apples appears in the background of a painting of this woman. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character from a Tennyson poem, depicted with long, flowy hair in that William Holman Hunt painting. A John William Waterhouse painting depicts this woman riding on a black barge.
As exemplified by Hunt's Lady of Shalott, many members of this group admired Tennyson's works. These British Romantics sought to return to a style present before a namesake Italian artist.
Tennyson asked this photographer to create illustrations for his collection Idylls of the King. She took close-ups of many Victorians such as John Herschel.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about attempts to restore the Ming dynasty:
answers: Koxinga [or Zheng Chenggong, Prince of Yanping]
parts: Resentment towards the succeeding Qing ("ching") dynasty came from the fact that their emperors were of this ethnicity. Their namesake region of China was turned into a Japanese puppet state during World War II.
This warlord established the Kingdom of Tungning ("toong-neeng") in his attempts to restore the Ming dynasty. The Kangxi emperor forced people to move inland to cut off this man's supplies.

The Qianlong ("ch'yen-long") Emperor quelled an uprising by this secret society, of which many Ming loyalists were members. The herbalist Wang Lun sparked the regrowth of this society in the 18th century.

bonuses.leadin: This novel was loosely adapted by Minae Mizumura into her book A True Novel. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel by Emily Brontë whose narrator, Nelly Dean, is paralleled by Fumiko Tsuchiya in Mizamura's novel.

In A True Novel, the central role of the Oiwake ("oh-ee-wah-keh") villa mirrors the central role of this country estate of the Linton family in Wuthering Heights, which is eventually acquired by Heathcliff.

Unlike Wuthering Heights, Mizamura's A True Novel has a prologue set in this city, though most of the novel is set in Tokyo and the countryside. Takashi returns to Tokyo after living in this city at the beginning of Kenzaburo Oe's novel The Silent Cry.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points, answer the following about taking music to new aeronautic heights:
parts: Astronaut Cady Coleman has performed solos on multiple variants of this high, transverse woodwind instrument while aboard the International Space Station, including a wooden Irish one.

This avant-garde German composer called for a string quartet to play aboard four separate helicopters in his "Helicopter String Quartet," which plays third scene of his opera Mittwoch aus Licht ("MEET-vokh aus leesht").

Though it is unfortunately played on Earth, the score of this Dadaist composition by George Antheil ("zhorzh on-TAYL") calls for three airplane propellers, as well as electric bells and player pianos.

bonuses.leadin: According to the Goodenough-Kanamori rules, the superexchange interaction for a 180 degree geometry has this property. For 10 points each:
answers: antiferromagnetism [do not accept or prompt on "ferromagnetism"]
Curie temperature [accept Pierre Curie or Marie Curie]
parts: Name this property which causes a coupling between iron[III] and oxygen in hemoglobin.
A spin-polarized "bridging" one of these molecules can mediate antiferromagnetic coupling between two metals. EDTA is a hexadentate one of these molecules.

The disappearance of antiferromagnetism above the Neel temperature is analogous to the disappearance of ferromagnetism above this temperature, which is named for the husband of the only person to win Nobel prizes in both physics and chemistry.

bonuses.leadin: Sganarelle ("sgah-nah-REL") is unaware of his daughter Lucinde's ("loo-SAHND'Z") love interests in a play titled for this profession, which reprises themes from an earlier play about a "flying" one. For 10 points each:
answers: doctor [or médecin; accept Doctor Cupid, or The Flying Doctor, or The Doctor in Spite of Himself, or L'Amour médecin, or Le Médecin volant, or Le Médecin malgré lui]
The Imaginary Cuckold [or Le Cocu imaginaire]
parts: Give this profession. In another play, Sganarelle is a woodcutter who inadvertently takes up this title profession after helping a different Lucinde.
This French author of Tartuffe played Sganarelle in many performances of those plays, which he wrote.

In this other Molière play, Sganarelle is falsely convinced that his wife is unfaithful, so he advises the audience to "never believe anything". The greedy Gorgibus plans to marry off his daughter in this play.
answers_formatted: doctor [or médecin; accept Doctor Cupid, or The Flying Doctor, or The Doctor in Spite of Himself, or L'Amour médecin, or Le Médecin volant, or Le Médecin malgré lui]
acceptable: The Doctor in Spite of Himself,

bonuses.leadin: This man may have coined the word "azure", since its first known use was in his glosses. For 10 points each:
answers: Rashi [or Shlomo Yitzchaki; or Salomon Isaacides; prompt on Salomon de Troyes; prompt on Rabbi Shlomo or Rabbi Salomon]
parts: Name this medieval rabbi from Troyes ("TRWAH") who wrote the first full Talmud commentary and a major commentary on the Tanakh. Commentaries on this man's commentaries are called Tosafot.
Rashi's commentary on this part of the Tanakh was one of his most influential works and the first Hebrew book to be printed; it's often studied to review this text's weekly portion.
When reviewing the Torah portion, the corresponding part of Rashi's commentary may uniquely be read in place of the required reading from this Aramaic translation of the Torah.
answers_formatted: Rashi [or Shlomo Yitzchaki; or Salomon Isaacides; prompt on Salomon de Troyes; prompt on Rabbi Shlomo or Rabbi Salomon]

bonuses.leadin: This concept and "ideology" title a 2019 book which argues we have returned to a "patrimonial" economy. For 10 points each:
answers: capital [accept Capital and Ideology or Capital in the 21st Century]
property rights [or properties; prompt on rights or ownership rights]
parts: Name this concept which titles that book by Thomas Piketty, as well as Piketty's best-known book. With land and labor, it is one of three major factors of production.
This economist has criticized Piketty for ignoring "dead capital" in the informal sector, which he analyzed in The Mystery of Capital.

To bring "dead capital" into the open, De Soto has proposed a blockchain to formalize these concepts in third-world countries. The Coase theorem suggests that externalities will be resolved if these concepts are well-defined.
answers_formatted: capital [accept Capital and Ideology or Capital in the 21st Century]

bonuses.leadin: Gottfried Leibniz may have borrowed the word "monad" from this philosopher's works, which were gifted to him by Franciscus van Helmont. For 10 points each:
answers: More [accept Henry More or Thomas More]
kabbalah [or kabbalistic thought; prompt on Jewish mysticism or Judaism]
parts: Name this Cambridge Platonist, best known for her treatise The Principles of the Most Ancient and Modern Philosophy.
Conway's treatise partly refutes an English philosopher with this surname who taught her and summarized his own views in his Divine Dialogues. Another philosopher with this surname wrote Utopia.

Conway extensively studied the version of this system of thought developed by Isaac Luria. Pico della Mirandola based his exegesis ("ex-EH-jeh-sis") of Genesis on this system's pardes ("par-DES") tradition.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about laws signed by John Adams targeting political opponents:
answers: Alien and Sedition Acts [prompt on partial answers]
friends AND enemies [accept Alien Friends Act AND Alien Enemies Act]
parts: This group of four laws passed in 1798 included one criminalizing speech against the government.

Among the Alien Acts were laws named for these two sorts of people -- one permitting deportation of citizens of countries at war with the US, the other permitting deportation of aliens accused of plotting against the US. Name both.

This other law criminalizes negotiations by unauthorized citizens with foreign governments. Nobody has ever been convicted of violating it, though Obama-era officials considered charging Michael Flynn under it.
answers_formatted: friends AND enemies [accept Alien Friends Act AND Alien Enemies Act]
acceptable: Alien Friends Act AND Alien Enemies Act

bonuses.leadin: Parseval's theorem can be used to show that this operation preserves the total energy carried by a signal. For 10 points each:
answers: interpolation [accept word forms such as interpolating]
parts: Name this operation which, for a function f(x) ("f of x"), is defined as (read slowly) the integral from minus infinity to infinity of f(x), times e raised to the minus 2 pi i s x, times dx.

For a Discrete Fourier Transform of length L ("ell"), the DFT performs this operation on the DTFT at the points 2π/L ("two-pi-over-ell"). This general task uses several known points of a function on an interval to approximate the function within the interval.
Multiplying the DFTs of two functions in the frequency domain is equivalent to performing this operation in the time domain.
